title: Morrison's high praise for India is a 'hedge against China'
text:
"[Australia is] trying to navigate how we build a new stable balance of power in a multi-polar world," said Professor Medcalf, the head of the National Security College at the Australian National University.

In his speech, Mr Morrison designated Australia an "Indo-Pacific" nation and emphasised the elevation of talks between the so-called Quad countries - the US, Australia, India and Japan - to foreign minister level.

"It is a key forum for exchanging views on challenges facing the region, including taking forward practical cooperation on maritime, terrorism and cyber issues," Mr Morrison said.

This speech shows the government is trying to firm up the relationship with India as a hedge against China. — Clinton Fernandes, UNSW

In contrast, the Prime Minister kept his remarks about Australia-China relations to the economic realm, reflecting the cooler diplomatic relations with Australia's largest export market. "I'd be happy to [visit China], but I'm not waiting by the phone. And nor should Australian prime ministers," Mr Morrison said during the question-and-answer session after his speech.

Allan Gyngell, former head of the government's intelligence analysis agency the Office of National Assessments, described Mr Morrison's speech as having an "anxious and inward-looking tone".

It was a "clear step away from the sort of Australian foreign policy articulated in the government’s 2017 Foreign Policy White Paper and towards the worldview of Trumpism and Brexit," he said.

"What is striking here are the adjectives" used to describe and rank Australia's international partners, Mr Gyngell said.

India was “a natural partner”, Japan provided “steadfast friendship and support”, and the US was "our past, our present and our future" and "the bedrock of our security", Mr Morrison said, on the heels of a week-long American trip.

Mr Morrison described China as a “comprehensive strategic partner" and noted its economic achievements before backing US President Donald Trump's calls for China to be stripped of its developing nation status, which entitles it to concessions under World Trade Organisation rules.

"It’s a balder, less optimistic tone than that of Morrison’s own Asialink speech a few weeks ago," Mr Gyngell said.

Describing India so favourably while confining Australia-China relations to economic terms sends a clear message to China, said Clinton Fernandes, Professor of International Relations at the University of NSW.

"This speech shows the government is trying to firm up the relationship with India as a hedge against China," he said.

"When you compare the language used to describe India, the PM's comments send a clear message that the government wants a confined, instrumental, economic relationship with China," Mr Fernandes said.
description: Analysts say the prime minister's warm tone when speaking about India is carefully calculated to send a message to Beijing.
